How US police use digital data to prosecute abortionsZack Whittaker0/30/2023

Court records reveal how police in the U.S. use text messages, emails, search history to prosecute people seeking abortions.

ArchivedRead

<body class="">

<div id="root">
	<div><!-- duplicate React-root div for styling -->
	<div class="content">
		<article class="article-container article--post ">
			<header class="article__header ">
	<div class="article__title-wrapper">
						<h1 class="article__title">How US police use digital data to prosecute abortions</h1>
		</div>

			<div class="article__byline-wrapper">
			
<div class="article__byline">
			<a href="https://techcrunch.com/author/">
			Runa Sandvik		</a>
		<span class="article__byline__meta">
						3 weeks		</span>
	</div>
		</div>
	
			<div class="article__featured-image-wrapper breakout">
			<img src="https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/05/GettyImages-1395069203.jpg?w=614" class="article__featured-image" />
		</div>
	</header>

			<div class="article-content">
				<p id="speakable-summary">In late April, police in Nebraska <a href="https://www.newschannelnebraska.com/story/46420551/multiple-people-cited-for-concealing-death-of-norfolk-infant" target="_blank" rel="noopener">received a tip</a> saying 17-year-old Celeste Burgess had given birth to a stillborn baby and buried the body. Officers soon learned that her mother, Jessica Burgess, and a friend had helped her with transportation and burial. The police issued citations for concealing the death of another person and false reporting. But in June, <a href="https://www.siouxlandproud.com/news/local-news/norfolk-woman-charged-for-burying-stillborn-faces-new-charges-of-providing-abortion/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">they also charged</a> Jessica with providing an abortion for her teenage daughter. Police had made the discovery after obtaining a warrant that <a href="https://about.fb.com/news/2022/08/meta-response-nebraska-abortion-case/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">required</a> Meta to hand over their conversations on Facebook Messenger. The messages, which were not <a href="https://www.facebook.com/help/messenger-app/1084673321594605" target="_blank" rel="noopener">encrypted</a>, showed the two had <a href="https://www.thedailybeast.com/facebook-fuels-abortion-charges-against-celeste-burgess-and-jessica-burgess-in-nebraska" target="_blank" rel="noopener">discussed</a> obtaining and using abortion pills.</p>
<p>Warrants for digital data are routine in police investigations, which makes sense, given how much time we spend online. Technology giants have for years responded to valid court orders for specific information sought by law enforcement, though some <a href="https://www.eff.org/who-has-your-back-2017" target="_blank" rel="noopener">companies have done more</a> to fight for our privacy than others. Millions of people now use apps that encrypt their calls and messages, like <a href="https://time.com/6238482/signals-president-meredith-whittaker-interview/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Signal</a> and <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2021/9/13/22672756/whatsapp-ceo-will-cathcart-interview-2021-propublica-privacy-encryption" target="_blank" rel="noopener">WhatsApp</a>, so that no one can access their messages  not even the providers themselves.</p>
<p>The case in Nebraska is not the first in which police have used digital data to prosecute an abortion, and it wont be the last. While digital data is rarely the main form of evidence, prosecutors use it to paint a picture in court; by showing messages sent to friends, internet searches or emails from an online pharmacy. As in the Burgess case, however, its often people around the women who first notify the authorities  a doctor or nurse, a family member or a friend of a friend.</p>
<p>When the U.S. Supreme Court overturned <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2022/06/24/tech-companies-respond-to-u-s-supreme-court-abortion-decision/">Roe v. Wade</a> last summer, it ended the constitutional right to abortion. In doing so, it gave states the power to regulate abortion or ban the procedure altogether, triggering a wave of abortion bans nationwide. <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2022/us/abortion-laws-roe-v-wade.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">At least 13 states</a> now ban abortion with few or no exceptions. Georgia recently <a href="https://apnews.com/article/abortion-health-georgia-atlanta-government-and-politics-2684684dc929966c1647094883cda2f8" target="_blank" rel="noopener">reinstated</a> a ban after six weeks of pregnancy. And in many states, the fight over abortion access is still taking place in courtrooms.</p>
<p>A week after the ruling, Google <a href="https://blog.google/technology/safety-security/protecting-peoples-privacy-on-health-topics/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">announced</a> it would delete location data for visits to abortion clinics and other medical facilities. The Electronic Frontier Foundation <a href="https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2022/06/effs-statement-dobbs-abortion-ruling" target="_blank" rel="noopener">said</a> we should review our privacy settings. The Digital Defense Fund <a href="https://digitaldefensefund.org/ddf-guides/abortion-privacy" target="_blank" rel="noopener">encouraged</a> us to use encrypted messaging apps. Some <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2022/05/05/roe-wade-privacy-period-tracking/">suggested</a> that we delete our period tracking apps. It may seem odd to dedicate so much attention to digital privacy in the context of our reproductive rights. But a look at prosecutions between 2011 and 2022 illustrates why these conversations are needed.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"></p>
<p>In May 2011, police in Idaho charged Jennie McCormack with inducing her own abortion. The 32-year-old couldnt afford a legal procedure. Instead, she took pills purchased online. NPR <a href="https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=150312812" target="_blank" rel="noopener">reported</a> that McCormack confided in a friend shortly after the abortion. It was this friends sister who told the police. When officers arrived at her home, they found the fetus wrapped up on her back porch.</p>
<p>McCormack admitted to the police that she self-induced an abortion after ingesting a pack of five pills. At trial, she told the court that the medication was FDA-approved, procured through the internet and prescribed by a physician. Years later, an appeals court <a href="https://www.courtlistener.com/opinion/2804418/jennie-mccormack-v-stephen-herzog/">noted</a> that McCormacks sister allegedly found unspecified abortion pills online, paid $200 for them and had them shipped to McCormack in Idaho.</p>
<p>At the time, McCormack faced up to five years in prison. The case was <a href="https://slate.com/human-interest/2015/06/jennie-linn-mccormack-case-court-strikes-down-idahos-abortion-laws.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">eventually</a> dismissed.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"></p>
<p>In March 2015, Indiana sentenced Purvi Patel to 20 years in prison for neglect of a dependent and feticide. <a href="https://www.indystar.com/story/news/crime/2014/08/26/judge-allows-feticide-charge-n-ind-woman/14657643/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Two years earlier</a>, Patel had gone to the hospital with bleeding after delivering a child at home. She first told the medical staff that she had been 10 to 12 weeks pregnant. But when questioned by two doctors, she admitted to giving birth and said the baby was stillborn.</p>
<p>Patel told the doctors she had put the body in a paper bag and placed it in a dumpster behind a Target store, not far from her familys restaurant. The hospital notified the police, who searched the area and recovered the bag. A doctor who participated in the search said the baby was cold and lifeless but was an otherwise normal, healthy appearing baby.</p>
<p><a href="https://s3.documentcloud.org/documents/1280086/patelpcaffidavit.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Court documents</a> show that police obtained a search warrant for Patel’s phone. An officer with “training in examining electronic devices” downloaded her text messages. In reviewing the data, the police found that she had discussed her abortion with “at least one friend.” Patel had also shared that shed obtained and taken abortion pills from Hong Kong.</p>
<p>An Indiana appeals court overturned the feticide conviction in July 2016. The court <a href="https://casetext.com/case/patel-v-state-46" target="_blank" rel="noopener">noted</a> that in searching Patels iPad, police found a customer service email from InternationalDrugMart.com.” The email confirmed that Patel had ordered mifepristone and misoprostol for $72. A detective ordered the same pills, presumably to confirm that it was possible to do so. Police also found Patel had visited a website titled “Abortion after Twelve Weeks.”</p>
<p>The court documents do not mention the type of phone Patel had or how police gained access to her messages. But the messages were at least three months old, suggesting that she likely did not delete the texts or the email from the online pharmacy.</p>
<p>Indianas attorney general <a href="https://www.indystar.com/story/news/crime/2016/09/01/purvi-patel-releases-feticide-conviction-overturned/89707582/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">decided</a> not to appeal the courts ruling. In September 2016, Patel was resentenced to 18 months for child neglect, less time than she had already served. The judge then ordered Patels immediate release.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"></p>
<p>In April 2015, police in Arkansas arrested Anne Bynum after she gave birth to a stillborn child at home. She was charged with concealing birth and abuse of a corpse. The state <a href="https://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2015/jun/05/nurse-charged-with-performing-abortion-/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">also</a> charged her friend, Karen Collins, with performing an abortion.</p>
<p>Bynum, who already had one child and worked a minimum-wage job, never told her parents about the pregnancy. When her pregnancy became difficult to hide, she took medications to induce labor.</p>
<p>In a<a href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2018/12/28/opinion/stillborn-murder-charge.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">video interview</a>, Bynum said she delivered the baby at home by herself, in the middle of the night. She was just beautiful. Really beautiful. But eyes closed, mouth closed. Complete stillness. Bynum wrapped up the remains and went to bed. The next day, she drove to the emergency room with the remains in the front passenger seat. Bynum said she gave birth last night, but she didnt make it. Medical staff determined it had been a stillbirth.</p>
<p>When the hospital discharged Bynum days later, she was arrested on her way home. The sheriff put her in handcuffs and placed her in the back of the police car. Bynums trial was brief, just two days of testimony and a few minutes of jury deliberation. The judge <a href="https://msmagazine.com/2019/02/13/anti-abortion-laws-hurt-pregnant-women/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">sentenced</a> her to six years in prison. An appeals court <a href="https://law.justia.com/cases/arkansas/court-of-appeals/2018/cr-16-879.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">reversed</a> the conviction in December 2018.</p>
<p>Exactly who notified the police remains unknown. The appeals court noted that Bynum told friends, her attorneys, and her priest about the pregnancy and of her intent to put the child up for adoption when it was born. On the morning after she gave birth, Bynum texted her attorney who advised her to go see a doctor. The attorney also called a funeral home and was advised to have Bynum take the fetal remains to the hospital.</p>
<p>Its unclear whether Bynum shared the texts herself, or if police recovered them another way.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"></p>
<p>In January 2018, Mississippi <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20180214065108/https://www.starkvilledailynews.com/content/prosecutors-suspect-newborn-death-researched-ways-end-her-pregnancy/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">charged</a> Latice Fisher with murder for the death of her newborn the year before. The Washington Post <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2022/07/03/abortion-data-privacy-prosecution/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">reported</a> that when paramedics arrived at her home, they found a baby in the toilet, lifeless and blue, the umbilical cord still attached. The baby was pronounced dead at the hospital. Fisher initially <a href="https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/23572966-a0150482" target="_blank" rel="noopener">said</a> she didnt know she was pregnant, but later admitted that she had been aware of the pregnancy for at least a month. She also admitted to conducting internet searches for how to have a miscarriage.</p>
<p>Fisher reportedly voluntarily surrendered her iPhone to police. Court records <a href="https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/23572966-a0150482" target="_blank" rel="noopener">show</a> her phones memory and data were then downloaded, including but not limited to Fishers past internet activity. While reviewing that data, investigators learned that Fisher had researched buy abortion pills, mifeprisone [sic] online, misoprostol online, and buy Misoprostol Abortion Pill Online. Fisher had also apparently purchased misoprostol immediately subsequent to these searches. <a href="https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/23572976-mississippi-v-latice-fisher-motion-for-additional-discovery" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Another</a> court document suggests police also searched her husbands phone.</p>
<p>While there is no evidence that Fisher took the pills, prosecutors used her digital data to argue that she intended to abort her pregnancy. The murder charge was eventually <a href="https://www.pregnancyjusticeus.org/victory-for-latice-fisher-in-mississippi/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">dismissed</a>.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"></p>
<p>Technology companies may not have many options for handling search warrants from the police, even when the investigations relate to abortion. But companies do get to decide how much digital data they collect about people and for how long they store the information. They also get to decide whether to offer end-to-end encryption, which would give people increased privacy for all of their messages. Following Russias invasion of Ukraine last year, Meta <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2022/03/01/instagram-rolls-out-encrypted-direct-messaging-in-ukraine-and-russia/">announced</a> its making encrypted one-to-one chats in Instagram available to adults in the two countries. And while Elon Musk said Twitter should <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2022/11/16/new-code-suggests-twitter-is-reviving-its-work-on-encrypted-dms/">end-to-end encrypt direct messages</a> prior to acquiring the company, its <a href="https://www.forbes.com/sites/thomasbrewster/2022/12/07/elon-musk-said-twitter-needed-encrypted-messages-its-on-hold/?sh=30af2ab49f93" target="_blank" rel="noopener">unclear</a> if this will actually happen.</p>
<p>Last year, <a href="https://themarkup.org/pixel-hunt/2022/06/15/facebook-and-anti-abortion-clinics-are-collecting-highly-sensitive-info-on-would-be-patients" target="_blank" rel="noopener">reporters found</a> that Facebook and anti-abortion clinics collect sensitive information on would-be patients. The Markup also<a href="https://themarkup.org/pixel-hunt/2022/07/01/online-abortion-pill-provider-hey-jane-used-tracking-tools-that-sent-visitor-data-to-meta-google-and-others" target="_blank" rel="noopener"> reported</a> that Hey Jane, an online abortion pill provider, employed a series of online trackers that follow users across the internet  until the journalists reached out about the practice. More recently, ProPublica <a href="https://www.propublica.org/article/websites-selling-abortion-pills-share-sensitive-data-with-google" target="_blank" rel="noopener">found</a> nine pharmacies selling abortion pills also sharing sensitive data with Google and other third-parties. All nine were recommended by <a href="https://www.plancpills.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Plan C</a>, which provides information about how to get abortion pills by mail. None responded to ProPublicas request for comment.</p>
<p>In <a href="https://jessica.substack.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Abortion, Every Day</a>, publisher Jessica Valenti <a href="https://jessica.substack.com/p/your-complicity-will-not-protect" target="_blank" rel="noopener">reminds</a> us that if you are white, have money, and the ability to travel to a state where abortion is legal  you will have a much easier time than those from marginalized communities. Everybody deserves access to reproductive health care. If the past decade is any indication, protecting essential abortion rights is going to require all of us, from doctors, nurses and attorneys to lawmakers, software engineers and voters.</p>
<p><em>Sarah Mitchell-Weed contributed research.</em></p>

agrees to double supercharger network, open to all EVs under Biden’s $7.5B charging plan"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Companies hoping to dip into the coffers of the Biden administration’s $7.5 billion EV charging initiative will have to meet a new set of requirements that even Tesla has agreed to.<\/p>\n<p>The Biden administration laid out Wednesday <a href=\"https:\/\/www.whitehouse.gov\/briefing-room\/statements-releases\/2023\/02\/15\/fact-sheet-biden-harris-administration-announces-new-standards-and-major-progress-for-a-made-in-america-national-network-of-electric-vehicle-chargers\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">the final standards<\/a> for its plan to build a national network of 500,000 electric vehicle chargers along highways, including a requirement that all EV chargers funded through the <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/08\/16\/winners-losers-abound-as-inflation-reduction-act-becomes-law\/\">Inflation Reduction Act<\/a> must be built in the United States. Specifically, the final assembly and all manufacturing processes for any iron or steel charger enclosures or housing must occur in the United States. And by July 2024, at least 55% of the cost of all components will need to be manufactured domestically, as well.<\/p>\n<p>All chargers are also required to use a standardized payment system that is smartphone-friendly and all connectors must use the “combined charging system” (CCS), which dominates in the U.S.<\/p>\n<p>Tesla doesn’t use CCS in North America; its vast Supercharger network in the U.S. uses a proprietary connector that only Tesla vehicles can use. That’s going to change, at least a little bit, under an agreement reached with the Biden administration.<\/p>\n<p>Tesla will open up a portion of its Supercharger and destination charger network to non-Tesla EVs. The company will make at least 7,500 chargers available for all EVs by the end of 2024, according to the White House. At least 3,500 of those will be 250 kW chargers located along highway corridors. All EV drivers will be able to access these stations using the Tesla app or website.<\/p>\n<p>Notably, Tesla has agreed to more than double its supercharger network.<\/p>\n<p>Tesla’s concession, which will allow it to access that $7.5 billion, comes just days after CEO Elon Musk met with White House officials. There’s been talk of Tesla opening up its EV chargers in the U.S. for years. In July 2022, a <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/07\/08\/white-house-tesla-to-expand-its-u-s-supercharger-network-to-other-evs-in-late-2022\/\">memo from the White House<\/a> indicated that Tesla would open its chargers to other EVs by the end of the year.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>That date came and went. Doubt was cast on whether Tesla would make the move after it shared its EV charging connector design in an effort to encourage network operators and automakers to adopt the technology and help make it the new standard in North America. It seemed, at the time, that Tesla was angling to make its technology the standard.<\/p>\n<p>Tesla has opened up its Supercharger network to other non-Tesla vehicles <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/02\/14\/tesla-opens-entire-supercharger-network-in-the-netherlands-to-all-evs\/\">in parts of Europe<\/a>. That transition has been easier since its chargers and vehicles use the CCS standard. The transition will likely be more complicated here, although there have been reports that the company has come up with a solution <a href=\"https:\/\/electrek.co\/2023\/01\/22\/tesla-leaks-magic-dock-ccs-adapter-opening-supercharger-network\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">called the Magic Dock<\/a> to give non-Tesla vehicles access to its proprietary chargers in the U.S.<\/p>\n<p>Tesla isn’t the only company to make commitments in order to access incentives in the Biden EV charging plan.<\/p>\n<p>GM previously announced a partnership with Pilot Company and EVgo to build a coast-to-coast network of 2,000 high-power 350 kW fast chargers at Pilot and Flying J travel centers along U.S. highways. The companies announced Wednesday that the first 200 chargers in this network are expected to be available for use by drivers in 2023. GM is also working with Canadian EV charging company Flo to <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/12\/07\/america-ev-charging-infrastructure-boost-gm-ford-dealers\/\">install 40,000 Level 2 units<\/a> in communities across the U.S. and Canada.<\/p>\n<p>Other previously announced partnerships include TravelCenters of America and Electrify America, which plan to install 1,000 EV chargers at 200 locations along major highways over the next five years, and an agreement between Mercedes-Benz, ChargePoint and MN8 Energy to install 400 charging hubs with more than 2,500 publicly accessible DC fast charging ports across the U.S. and Canada.<\/p>\n<p>ChargePoint, Volvo Car and Starbucks have also announced a partnership to add 60 DC fast chargers at\u00a0up to 15 locations along the 1,350-mile pilot route between Seattle and Denver to be completed by summer 2023.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Companies hoping to dip into the coffers of the Biden administration’s $7.5 billion EV charging initiative will have to meet a new set of requirements that even Tesla has agreed to. takes aim at Google and Microsoft with multimodal chat search"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><a href=\"http:\/\/you.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">You.com<\/a> founder Richard Socher knows that his company has always been a David going after the Goliath in search, Google, and to a lesser extent Microsoft. He likes to point out that his company built search based on generative AI in December,<a href=\"https:\/\/blog.you.com\/introducing-youchat-the-ai-search-assistant-that-lives-in-your-search-engine-eff7badcd655\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> several months before<\/a> the other giant search players made their announcements.<\/p>\n<p>Today, the company is announcing it\u2019s taking that head start and building on it with multimodal search. That means it can add elements beyond text to help answer a question more precisely. So say you ask a question such as “Which company has the most CRM market share,” you will get the answer “Salesforce,” and if you follow up with “What is Saleforce’s stock price?”, you will get a stock chart instead of a text-based answer.<\/p>\n<p>Socher says that\u2019s a big leap forward for chat-based search, and puts his company ahead of his much larger competitors. \u201cInstead of making up a bunch of numbers, which every other language model would do, we’ll just show you our stock app right there inside the conversation,\u201d Socher told TechCrunch.<\/p>\n<p>He believes that\u2019s a much more effective way to answer that kind of question and these different modalities can be applied to other questions depending on the context. \u201cIt’s a big step forward to get large language models to be multimodal in the sense of the different modalities being text, but also code, but also tables, and also graphs and images and interactive elements — and sometimes that is the best way to answer your question. I truly believe that this better way to represent the answer to this question than any text could be,\u201d he said.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2485944\" style=\"width: 3180px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2485944\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"wp-image-2485944 size-full\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/02\/crm-info.jpg\" alt=\"You.com search involving CRM vendors, displaying a stock chart as part of the results.\" width=\"3170\" height=\"1443\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/02\/crm-info.jpg 3170w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/02\/crm-info.jpg?resize=150,68 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/02\/crm-info.jpg?resize=300,137 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/02\/crm-info.jpg?resize=768,350 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/02\/crm-info.jpg?resize=680,310 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/02\/crm-info.jpg?resize=1536,699 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/02\/crm-info.jpg?resize=2048,932 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/02\/crm-info.jpg?resize=1200,546 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/02\/crm-info.jpg?resize=50,23 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 3170px) 100vw, 3170px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2485944\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">You.com displays charts or other elements when it helps to answer a question more than text would.<strong> Image Credits:<\/strong> You.com<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>You.com launched <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/12\/08\/former-salesforce-chief-scientist-announces-new-search-engine-to-take-on-google\/\">at the end of 2020<\/a> with the belief that there was room for another search engine, based more on AI. That\u2019s a notion that the search market has caught up with, but Socher sees room for a fresh approach, one that the incumbents can\u2019t offer.<\/p>\n<p>As he told TechCrunch at the time of his company\u2019s <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/07\/14\/you-com-raises-25m-to-fuel-its-ai-powered-search-engine\/\">$25 million funding round<\/a> last summer, he wants You.com to be the anti-Google.\u00a0\u201cGoogle is a monolithic, monopolistic search engine that is closed and has ultimately weaponized AI against users for the sake of serving its true purpose: advertising. We are building You.com as a search platform that is open and emphasizes directly serving user needs with You.com apps instead of bombarding people with ads,\u201d he told TechCrunch\u2019s Kyle Wiggers at the time.<\/p>\n<p>Socher is reluctant to discuss the technology behind his company\u2019s search at this point, concerned that his competitors will be able to use it against him, but he says at some point he will reveal the secret sauce he is using to build his company\u2019s search solution.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cWe don’t really share right now how we built it. I know a lot of people are super curious about how we are building all this stuff. But a lot of people are trying to copy what we’re doing. And it just doesn’t really make sense until we’re at least default live or profitable as a startup to share all our technology, or even high level or details on how we’re doing any of it,\u201d he said.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>He says that the company is growing double-digit percentage growth every month, and they have millions of people using the site every day now. They are still considering how to monetize, but it won\u2019t be like Google or Bing.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cWe don’t have to make $500 million a day. We don’t have that pressure right now as a startup. But we will think about monetization this year, and we’ll try to explore different paths,\u201d he said. That includes private ads, subscriptions to different add-ons like one they have that helps users write essays and blog posts for a couple of dollars a week, and they could also open the platform to build third-party apps like the stock app that displays a stock chart.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cYou can allow that third-party app to just sell a service, and when that’s relevant to the user, and the user wants to buy whatever that company sells, then we get a cut of that. So it’s sort of monetizing the end of the funnel rather than the beginning of the funnel, which is what ads do,\u201d he said.<\/p>\n<p>He certainly understands that he\u2019s up against some formidable competition, but he believes that You.com has found a way to differentiate itself from its competitors.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cIt’s certainly a tough space to compete in, for sure, and you need to build something that is both unique and different, but at the same time good enough to capture most of the things that people currently want from their search engine,\u201d he said.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cAnd that’s what we’ve done, and it’s part of why we’re able to grow now and provide a fresh new perspective on what a search engine can or should be able to help you with.\u201d<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>You.com founder Richard Socher knows that his company has always been a David going after the Goliath in search, Google, and to a lesser extent Microsoft. ed":"Passwordless authentication startup Descope lands whopping $53M seed round"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Capital might be harder to come by than it once was in startup land, but some firms are bucking the trend — hard. Take <a href=\"https:\/\/www.descope.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Descope<\/a>, for example, which today announced that it raised a whopping $53 million in seed funding for its “developer-first” authentication and user management platform.<\/p>\n<p>The money came from Lightspeed Venture Partners and GGV Capital with additional funds contributed by Dell Technologies Capital, TechAviv, J Ventures, Cerca, Unusual Ventures, Silicon Valley CISO Investments and individual investors CrowdStrike CEO George Kurtz and Microsoft chairman John W. Thompson. It’ll be used, Descope co-founder and CEO Slavik Markovich says, to grow Descope’s product capabilities, invest in research and support open source initiatives around authentication, authorization and user management.<\/p>\n<p>“The Descope platform helps developers add authentication, user management and authorization capabilities to their business-to-consumer and business-to-business apps with just a few lines of code,” Markovich told TechCrunch in an email interview. “It helps apps accelerate their time to market, increase the efficiency of their engineering resources, reduce user friction and prevent a wide variety of identity-based cyberattacks.”<\/p>\n<p>Why the large cash infusion — particularly large for a seed round — in a dev-focused startup, you might ask? Markovich says that it came down to timing. In tight economies, organizations feel the pressure to shift software development efforts to initiatives that’ll move the needle for business. Descope enables them to achieve this, Markovich avers, by outsourcing many necessary — but not revenue-generating — authentication and user management app components, freeing up dev teams.<\/p>\n<p>Descope was founded last April by the members of the core team that built the security operations platform Demisto, which Palo Alto Networks <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/02\/19\/palo-alto-networks-to-acquire-demisto-for-560m\/\">acquired<\/a> in March 2019. While at Demisto, the team says that they experienced the pain of building authentication and user management functionality — including password management, single sign-on, tenant management and roles and permissions — firsthand. It turned into a multiyear investment, Markovich says — not to mention a massive time sink.<\/p>\n<p>“With Descope, the team\u2019s vision is to ‘descope’ (hence the name) authentication and user management from every app developer\u2019s daily work, so that they can focus on business-critical initiatives without worrying about building, updating and maintaining authentication,” Markovich said.<\/p>\n<p>Markovich doesn’t deny that there’s a wealth of competition in the user authentication space, like <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/06\/23\/conductorone-is-bringing-automation-to-identity-and-access-management-with-15m-investment\/\">ConductorOne<\/a>, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/11\/18\/stytch-api-passwordless-unicorn\/\">Stytch<\/a>, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/06\/22\/transmit-security-raises-543m-series-a-to-kill-off-the-password\/\">Transmit Security<\/a> and Okta-backed <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/06\/07\/auth0-founder-code-boss\/\">Auth0<\/a>. (In 2021, VC investment in identity management startups <a href=\"https:\/\/news.crunchbase.com\/venture\/venture-investment-identity-management-authentication-incode-transmit-socure-okta\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">reached<\/a> $3.2 billion, according to Crunchbase — a record at the time.) But he asserts that Descope is differentiated by its workflow and screen editor, which are drag-and-drop as opposed to code-based and intended to let developers customize authentication flows for apps without having to write any code.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>“This greatly speeds up time to market and also makes it easier to modify and update user journeys flows with time,” Markovich said. “These no-code workflows abstract away the complexity of building authentication while still giving app builders control over their user experience and user interface.”<\/p>\n<p>Beyond the editors, Descope offers a set of software development kits and APIs that allow customers to add passwordless authentication methods (think biometrics, risk-based authentication and multifactor authentication) to existing apps and services. Security teams get app security flows that they can review and audit for compliance.<\/p>\n<p>So why launch Descope now? There’s no shortage of rival apps, after all. But Markovich says that the team felt the industry had reached an inflection point. Over 66% of smartphone users are expected to use device-native biometrics instead of passwords by 2024, he noted, citing <a href=\"https:\/\/www.paymentsjournal.com\/by-2024-how-many-smartphone-owners-will-use-biometrics\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">data<\/a> from Mercator, while authentication protocols like FIDO2, WebAuthn and passkeys have set the foundation for a passwordless future. The next step, Markovich argues, is enabling developers to easily add passwordless authentication methods alongside others such as social logins, one-time passwords and magic links to their apps.<\/p>\n<p>There’s demand to be sure. According to a recent <a href=\"https:\/\/venturebeat.com\/security\/secureauth-finds-that-85-of-it-professionals-plan-to-adopt-passwordless-technology\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">survey<\/a> by Enterprise Strategy Group, 85% of IT and cybersecurity professionals agree the adoption of passwordless technology is among their top strategic initiatives.<\/p>\n<p>“Passwords are not only the leading cause of security breaches, but are also known to cause friction throughout a user journey — leading to churn and a negative experience for end customers,” Markovich continued. “The proliferation of cybersecurity attacks due to poor identity and authentication practices such as credential stuffing, bot attacks, session hijacking, brute force attacks and other types of password compromise. Authentication and user management are critical parts of any digital application.”<\/p>\n<p>It’s a tough time to launch a startup regardless, what with less access to capital and uncertainty around the wider economic landscape. Descope doesn’t have much traction to point to, either — the platform’s in private beta and Markovich declined to comment on revenue or the size of the company’s customer base.<\/p>\n<p>Still, Markovich claims that Descope is “well-positioned” to weather a slowdown in tech, and perhaps even uniquely positioned considering challenging economies are frequently accompanied by increased fraud and cyberattacks.<\/p>\n<p>“The Descope team is full of seasoned startup operators that have built companies in both bull and bear markets,” Markovich said. “They are experienced in allotting capital towards initiatives that move the needle for business in a sustainable, customer-centric and efficient manner.”<\/p>\n<p>We’ll have to wait and see whether that turns out to be the case.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Capital might be harder to come by than it once was in startup land, but some firms are bucking the trend — hard. NFTs are growing quickly as community sees long-term potential"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\">Ordinals, an NFT-like<\/span> project on the Bitcoin blockchain, has gained momentum over the past month, signaling a chance that a new frontier may be on the horizon for the biggest cryptocurrency. But in order to be the biggest, experts say its accessibility and security need to be improved.<\/p>\n<p>Over 90,000 <a href=\"https:\/\/ordinals.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Ordinals<\/a> have been <a href=\"https:\/\/docs.ordinals.com\/inscriptions.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">inscribed<\/a> \u2014 which is jargon for created (or minted) \u2014 on the Bitcoin blockchain to date, according to Dune Analytics <a href=\"https:\/\/dune.com\/dataalways\/ordinals\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">data<\/a>. Ordinals hit an all-time high on February 9 for the number of mints at over 20,000 that day.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cIt seems foolish to say this won\u2019t be a very impactful revelation,\u201d Nick Hansen, CEO and co-founder of Luxor, told TechCrunch. \u201cI can\u2019t predict the future, but given current trends and hockey stick growth, we\u2019re definitely headed to more Bitcoin NFT inscriptions now than fewer.\u201d<\/p>\n<p>The Ordinals project isn\u2019t the first to try bringing NFTs onto the Bitcoin blockchain. Counterparty was the first platform to inscribe NFTs on Bitcoin\u2019s network with the Rare Pepe collection in 2014. Although Rare Pepe didn\u2019t do much to boost mass demand, one of its NFTs from 2016 sold for $3.6 million at a <a href=\"https:\/\/metaverse.sothebys.com\/natively-digital\/lots\/pepenopoulos\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Sotheby\u2019s auction<\/a> about a year ago.<\/p>\n<p>Ordinals stands out as a project for directly inscribing onto satoshis, the smallest denomination of bitcoin (equivalent to 100 millionth of a bitcoin), without needing another chain or token. \u201cThe unique thing about Ordinals is its putting the image literally in the blockchain,\u201d Muneeb Ali, co-founder of Stacks and CEO of Trust Machines, said. \u201cOther NFTs usually link to the images on-chain.\u201d<\/p>\n<p>Even though Ordinals and Bitcoin NFTs in general are exploding, it\u2019s still in very early stages, especially when compared to behemoths like Ethereum and Solana.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cIt\u2019s very clunky because it\u2019s day one,\u201d said Alex Adelman, the co-founder and CEO of Bitcoin rewards platform Lolli. \u201cIt\u2019s like the Wild West, but that\u2019s how NFTs felt back in the day, as well with Ethereum.\u201d<\/p>\n<p>Ethereum and Solana now have a huge leg up when it comes to infrastructure, communities, and trading platforms and collections. In the past 30 days, Ethereum, the No. 1 blockchain by NFT sales volume, saw volumes increase 35.5% to $860 million across over 178,000 buyers, according to CryptoSlam <a href=\"https:\/\/www.cryptoslam.io\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">data<\/a>. Solana, the second-largest blockchain by NFT sales volume, fell 15.6% to $114.6 million across over 80,000 buyers during the same time period.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cEthereum has proven there\u2019s a market for this already and is essentially stealing market share based on demand,\u201d Adelman said.<\/p>\n<p>So, inherently Bitcoin NFTs will compete with other major NFT ecosystems, Hansen said. \u201cI think we\u2019ll most likely see a lot of Ethereum NFT projects building bridges to move to Bitcoin.\u201d<\/p>\n<p>When people build on Bitcoin, it gets a lot more attention, Ali said. \u201cSome people think it\u2019s more valuable than other chains because it\u2019s unclear if those other chains will be around, but bitcoin will likely be around in 10, 20 or 50 years from now.\u201d<\/p>\n<p>But this expansion won\u2019t happen overnight, and the current infrastructure for Bitcoin NFTs is extremely clunky and still done manually on many fronts. For example, many people are legitimately completing inscriptions manually rather than through a service like an NFT marketplace.<\/p>\n<p><div yields to activist pressure with harsh new policies for engineers, salespeople"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Salesforce is looking at new ways to cut costs as <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/01\/26\/as-activist-investors-target-salesforce-whats-next-for-the-crm-giant\/\">activist investors<\/a> continue to put pressure on the company. Today,<a href=\"https:\/\/www.businessinsider.com\/salesforce-employee-performance-metrics-less-severance-layoffs-2023-2?fbclid=IwAR1Szy0WWJc0Pino81lzNDCiVM1hn1uVXs7uigrboVBdWmYBksYTkT4owAU\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> Insider was reporting<\/a> that the company is implementing much stricter performance measurements for engineering, with some salespeople being put under pressure to quit or succumb to harsh performance policies of their own. This is consistent with what sources have been telling TechCrunch.<\/p>\n<p>This could include performance reviews based on the quantity of code produced for engineers, a flawed way to measure engineering productivity, which encourages quantity over quality. While salespeople are being put between a rock and a hard place, being asked to choose between signing a strict one-month performance improvement plan or taking an exit package.<\/p>\n<p>When asked about this, Salesforce responded with this comment: \u201cOur performance management process drives accountability and rewards excellence.\u201d The company did not elaborate or answer follow-up questions regarding the timing or details of this policy.<\/p>\n<p>TechCrunch has also been hearing that the company is mandating a return to the office, and according to a Salesforce spokesperson, it\u2019s now up to the managers to decide. \u201cOur hybrid approach empowers leaders to make decisions for their teams about which jobs need to be in the office or remote.\u201d<\/p>\n<p>That\u2019s an interesting attitude shift for a company has <a href=\"https:\/\/www.salesforce.com\/news\/press-releases\/2020\/06\/15\/introducing-salesforce-anywhere-technology-enabling-the-all-digital-work-from-anywhere-world\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">been promoting the idea<\/a> of the \u201call digital, work-from-anywhere workplace\u201d since the pandemic hit in 2020, something they call the <a href=\"https:\/\/www.salesforce.com\/news\/stories\/faq-how-salesforce-and-slack-help-companies-build-their-digital-hq\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Digital HQ.<\/a> It\u2019s a big part of why the CRM leader <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/12\/01\/salesforce-buys-slack\/\">spent almost $28 billion<\/a> to buy Slack in 2020.<\/p>\n<p>But neither is it surprising since CEO and chair<a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/12\/19\/benioffs-reported-slack-statement-muddles-message-about-salesforces-view-of-wfh\/\">\u00a0Marc Benioff practically telegraphed <\/a>this at the end of last year, suggesting that folks working from home weren\u2019t as productive.<\/p>\n<p>All of this is probably related to the fact that activist investors — including Elliott Management, Starboard Value, ValueAct and Inclusive Capital — <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/02\/03\/can-4-activist-investors-play-nice-in-the-salesforce-sandbox\/\">have been circling the company<\/a>, undoubtedly putting tons of pressure on Benioff to increase productivity and cut costs. These firms are a big part of the reason Salesforce announced that <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/01\/04\/salesforce-to-cut-workforce-by-10-after-hiring-too-many-people-during-the-pandemic\/\">it was cutting 10%<\/a> of its workforce in January, a process that has been handled badly with layoff notices <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/02\/02\/some-salesforce-employees-just-found-out-theyre-part-of-the-10-layoff-announced-last-month\/\">coming in dribs and drabs<\/a>, leaving workers anxious and uncertain.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>Ray Wang, founder and principal analyst at Constellation Research, blames Boston Consulting Group, which he says was brought in at the behest of the activists to deal with the cuts and implement new performance review policies. \u201cFrom what we know, BCG made some significant recommendations on how salespeople and developers should be measured to improve productivity,\u201d Wang told TechCrunch.<\/p>\n<p>Wang says that whether you think this approach is a good idea or not depends on your perspective. \u201cIf I was an investor, I would advocate for this approach, but if I was the owner-founder, I would want something less harsh and more nuanced,\u201d he said.<\/p>\n<p>Wang isn\u2019t a fan of how the activists have handled this, calling them \u201cvulture firms.\u201d While he does agree with their assertion that Salesforce overpaid for bad acquisitions, he believes these firms lack an understanding of how to run a company like Salesforce, and they are ultimately doing more harm than good.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cThe vulture firms do not have a good understanding of the investment levels in R&D that are needed for innovation to continue, nor did they understand what level of marketing spend Salesforce needs to remain top of mind for execs,\u201d Wang said.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cThey don\u2019t add any value. They come in to just make money on the arbitrage and they leave the firms more damaged than when they were before they were taken over,\u201d he said.<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Salesforce is looking at new ways to cut costs as activist investors continue to put pressure on the company. Link","children":[]}]},"entities":{"posts":[{"id":2476250,"date":"2023-01-27T12:11:58","date_gmt":"2023-01-27T20:11:58","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2476250"},"modified":"2023-01-30T13:03:12","modified_gmt":"2023-01-30T21:03:12","slug":"digital-data-roe-wade-reproductive-privacy","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/01\/27\/digital-data-roe-wade-reproductive-privacy\/","title":{"rendered":"How US police use digital data to prosecute abortions"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">In late April, police in Nebraska <a href=\"https:\/\/www.newschannelnebraska.com\/story\/46420551\/multiple-people-cited-for-concealing-death-of-norfolk-infant\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">received a tip<\/a> saying 17-year-old Celeste Burgess had given birth to a stillborn baby and buried the body. Officers soon learned that her mother, Jessica Burgess, and a friend had helped her with transportation and burial. The police issued citations for concealing the death of another person and false reporting. But in June, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.siouxlandproud.com\/news\/local-news\/norfolk-woman-charged-for-burying-stillborn-faces-new-charges-of-providing-abortion\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">they also charged<\/a> Jessica with providing an abortion for her teenage daughter. Police had made the discovery after obtaining a warrant that <a href=\"https:\/\/about.fb.com\/news\/2022\/08\/meta-response-nebraska-abortion-case\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">required<\/a> Meta to hand over their conversations on Facebook Messenger. The messages, which were not <a href=\"https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/help\/messenger-app\/1084673321594605\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">encrypted<\/a>, showed the two had <a href=\"https:\/\/www.thedailybeast.com\/facebook-fuels-abortion-charges-against-celeste-burgess-and-jessica-burgess-in-nebraska\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">discussed<\/a> obtaining and using abortion pills.<\/p>\n<p>Warrants for digital data are routine in police investigations, which makes sense, given how much time we spend online. Technology giants have for years responded to valid court orders for specific information sought by law enforcement, though some <a href=\"https:\/\/www.eff.org\/who-has-your-back-2017\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">companies have done more<\/a> to fight for our privacy than others. Millions of people now use apps that encrypt their calls and messages, like <a href=\"https:\/\/time.com\/6238482\/signals-president-meredith-whittaker-interview\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Signal<\/a> and <a href=\"https:\/\/www.theverge.com\/2021\/9\/13\/22672756\/whatsapp-ceo-will-cathcart-interview-2021-propublica-privacy-encryption\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">WhatsApp<\/a>, so that no one can access their messages \u2014 not even the providers themselves.<\/p>\n<p>The case in Nebraska is not the first in which police have used digital data to prosecute an abortion, and it won\u2019t be the last. While digital data is rarely the main form of evidence, prosecutors use it to paint a picture in court; by showing messages sent to friends, internet searches or emails from an online pharmacy. As in the Burgess case, however, it\u2019s often people around the women who first notify the authorities \u2014 a doctor or nurse, a family member or a friend of a friend.<\/p>\n<p>When the U.S. Supreme Court overturned <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/06\/24\/tech-companies-respond-to-u-s-supreme-court-abortion-decision\/\">Roe v. Wade<\/a> last summer, it ended the constitutional right to abortion. In doing so, it gave states the power to regulate abortion or ban the procedure altogether, triggering a wave of abortion bans nationwide. <a href=\"https:\/\/www.nytimes.com\/interactive\/2022\/us\/abortion-laws-roe-v-wade.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">At least 13 states<\/a> now ban abortion with few or no exceptions. Georgia recently <a href=\"https:\/\/apnews.com\/article\/abortion-health-georgia-atlanta-government-and-politics-2684684dc929966c1647094883cda2f8\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">reinstated<\/a> a ban after six weeks of pregnancy. And in many states, the fight over abortion access is still taking place in courtrooms.<\/p>\n<p>A week after the ruling, Google <a href=\"https:\/\/blog.google\/technology\/safety-security\/protecting-peoples-privacy-on-health-topics\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">announced<\/a> it would delete location data for visits to abortion clinics and other medical facilities. The Electronic Frontier Foundation <a href=\"https:\/\/www.eff.org\/deeplinks\/2022\/06\/effs-statement-dobbs-abortion-ruling\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">said<\/a> we should review our privacy settings. The Digital Defense Fund <a href=\"https:\/\/digitaldefensefund.org\/ddf-guides\/abortion-privacy\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">encouraged<\/a> us to use encrypted messaging apps. Some <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/05\/roe-wade-privacy-period-tracking\/\">suggested<\/a> that we delete our period tracking apps. It may seem odd to dedicate so much attention to digital privacy in the context of our reproductive rights. But a look at prosecutions between 2011 and 2022 illustrates why these conversations are needed.<\/p>\n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">\u2014<\/p>\n<p>In May 2011, police in Idaho charged Jennie McCormack with inducing her own abortion. The 32-year-old couldn\u2019t afford a legal procedure. Instead, she took pills purchased online. NPR <a href=\"https:\/\/www.npr.org\/templates\/story\/story.php?storyId=150312812\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">reported<\/a> that McCormack confided in a friend shortly after the abortion. It was this friend\u2019s sister who told the police. When officers arrived at her home, they found the fetus wrapped up on her back porch.<\/p>\n<p>McCormack admitted to the police that she self-induced an abortion after ingesting a pack of five pills. At trial, she told the court that the medication was \u201cFDA-approved,\u201d \u201cprocured through the internet\u201d and \u201cprescribed by a physician.\u201d Years later, an appeals court <a href=\"https:\/\/www.courtlistener.com\/opinion\/2804418\/jennie-mccormack-v-stephen-herzog\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">noted<\/a> that \u201cMcCormack\u2019s sister allegedly found unspecified abortion pills online, paid $200 for them and had them shipped to McCormack in Idaho.\u201d<\/p>\n<p>At the time, McCormack faced up to five years in prison. The case was <a href=\"https:\/\/slate.com\/human-interest\/2015\/06\/jennie-linn-mccormack-case-court-strikes-down-idahos-abortion-laws.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">eventually<\/a> dismissed.<\/p>\n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">\u2014<\/p>\n<p>In March 2015, Indiana sentenced Purvi Patel to 20 years in prison for neglect of a dependent and feticide. <a href=\"https:\/\/www.indystar.com\/story\/news\/crime\/2014\/08\/26\/judge-allows-feticide-charge-n-ind-woman\/14657643\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Two years earlier<\/a>, Patel had gone to the hospital with bleeding after delivering a child at home. She first told the medical staff that she had been 10 to 12 weeks pregnant. But when questioned by two doctors, she admitted to giving birth and said the baby was stillborn.<\/p>\n<p>Patel told the doctors she had put the body in a paper bag and placed it in a dumpster behind a Target store, not far from her family\u2019s restaurant. The hospital notified the police, who searched the area and recovered the bag. A doctor who participated in the search said \u201cthe baby was cold and lifeless\u201d but \u201cwas an otherwise normal, healthy appearing baby.\u201d<\/p>\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/s3.documentcloud.org\/documents\/1280086\/patelpcaffidavit.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Court documents<\/a> show that police obtained a search warrant for Patel’s phone. An officer with “training in examining electronic devices” downloaded her text messages. In reviewing the data, the police found that she had discussed her abortion with “at least one friend.” Patel had also shared that she\u2019d obtained and taken abortion pills from Hong Kong.<\/p>\n<p>An Indiana appeals court overturned the feticide conviction in July 2016. The court <a href=\"https:\/\/casetext.com\/case\/patel-v-state-46\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">noted<\/a> that in searching Patel\u2019s iPad, \u201cpolice found a customer service email from InternationalDrugMart.com.” The email confirmed that Patel had ordered mifepristone and misoprostol for $72. A detective ordered the same pills, presumably to confirm that it was possible to do so. Police also found Patel had visited a website titled “Abortion after Twelve Weeks.”<\/p>\n<p>The court documents do not mention the type of phone Patel had or how police gained access to her messages. But the messages were at least three months old, suggesting that she likely did not delete the texts or the email from the online pharmacy.<\/p>\n<p>Indiana\u2019s attorney general <a href=\"https:\/\/www.indystar.com\/story\/news\/crime\/2016\/09\/01\/purvi-patel-releases-feticide-conviction-overturned\/89707582\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">decided<\/a> not to appeal the court\u2019s ruling. In September 2016, Patel was resentenced to 18 months for child neglect, less time than she had already served. The judge then ordered Patel\u2019s immediate release.<\/p>\n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">\u2014<\/p>\n<p>In April 2015, police in Arkansas arrested Anne Bynum after she gave birth to a stillborn child at home. She was charged with concealing birth and abuse of a corpse. The state <a href=\"https:\/\/www.arkansasonline.com\/news\/2015\/jun\/05\/nurse-charged-with-performing-abortion-\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">also<\/a> charged her friend, Karen Collins, with performing an abortion.<\/p>\n<p>Bynum, who already had one child and worked a minimum-wage job, never told her parents about the pregnancy. When her pregnancy became difficult to hide, she took medications to induce labor.<\/p>\n<p>In a\u00a0<a href=\"https:\/\/www.nytimes.com\/interactive\/2018\/12\/28\/opinion\/stillborn-murder-charge.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">video interview<\/a>, Bynum said she delivered the baby at home by herself, in the middle of the night. \u201cShe was just beautiful. Really beautiful. But eyes closed, mouth closed. Complete stillness.\u201d Bynum wrapped up the remains and went to bed. The next day, she drove to the emergency room with the remains in the front passenger seat. Bynum said she \u201cgave birth last night, but she didn\u2019t make it.\u201d Medical staff determined it had been a stillbirth.<\/p>\n<p>When the hospital discharged Bynum days later, she was arrested on her way home. The sheriff put her in handcuffs and placed her in the back of the police car. Bynum\u2019s trial was brief, just two days of testimony and a few minutes of jury deliberation. The judge <a href=\"https:\/\/msmagazine.com\/2019\/02\/13\/anti-abortion-laws-hurt-pregnant-women\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">sentenced<\/a> her to six years in prison. An appeals court <a href=\"https:\/\/law.justia.com\/cases\/arkansas\/court-of-appeals\/2018\/cr-16-879.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">reversed<\/a> the conviction in December 2018.<\/p>\n<p>Exactly who notified the police remains unknown. The appeals court noted that \u201cBynum told friends, her attorneys, and her priest about the pregnancy and of her intent to put the child up for adoption when it was born.\u201d On the morning after she gave birth, Bynum texted her attorney \u201cwho advised her to go see a doctor.\u201d The attorney also called a funeral home and \u201cwas advised to have Bynum take the fetal remains to the hospital.\u201d<\/p>\n<p>It\u2019s unclear whether Bynum shared the texts herself, or if police recovered them another way.<\/p>\n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">\u2014<\/p>\n<p>In January 2018, Mississippi <a href=\"https:\/\/web.archive.org\/web\/20180214065108\/https:\/\/www.starkvilledailynews.com\/content\/prosecutors-suspect-newborn-death-researched-ways-end-her-pregnancy\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">charged<\/a> Latice Fisher with murder for the death of her newborn the year before. The Washington Post <a href=\"https:\/\/www.washingtonpost.com\/technology\/2022\/07\/03\/abortion-data-privacy-prosecution\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">reported<\/a> that when paramedics arrived at her home, they found \u201ca baby in the toilet, lifeless and blue, the umbilical cord still attached.\u201d The baby was pronounced dead at the hospital. Fisher initially <a href=\"https:\/\/www.documentcloud.org\/documents\/23572966-a0150482\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">said<\/a> she didn\u2019t know she was pregnant, but later admitted that she had been aware of the pregnancy for at least a month. She also admitted to conducting internet searches for how to have a miscarriage.<\/p>\n<p>Fisher reportedly \u201cvoluntarily surrendered\u201d her iPhone to police. Court records <a href=\"https:\/\/www.documentcloud.org\/documents\/23572966-a0150482\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">show<\/a> her phone\u2019s \u201cmemory and data were then downloaded, including but not limited to Fisher\u2019s past internet activity.\u201d While reviewing that data, investigators learned that Fisher had researched \u201cbuy abortion pills, mifeprisone [sic] online, misoprostol online,\u201d and \u201cbuy Misoprostol Abortion Pill Online.\u201d Fisher had also \u201capparently purchased misoprostol immediately subsequent to these searches.\u201d <a href=\"https:\/\/www.documentcloud.org\/documents\/23572976-mississippi-v-latice-fisher-motion-for-additional-discovery\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Another<\/a> court document suggests police also searched her husband\u2019s phone.<\/p>\n<p>While there is no evidence that Fisher took the pills, prosecutors used her digital data to argue that she intended to abort her pregnancy. The murder charge was eventually <a href=\"https:\/\/www.pregnancyjusticeus.org\/victory-for-latice-fisher-in-mississippi\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">dismissed<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">\u2014<\/p>\n<p>Technology companies may not have many options for handling search warrants from the police, even when the investigations relate to abortion. But companies do get to decide how much digital data they collect about people and for how long they store the information. They also get to decide whether to offer end-to-end encryption, which would give people increased privacy for all of their messages. Following Russia\u2019s invasion of Ukraine last year, Meta <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/03\/01\/instagram-rolls-out-encrypted-direct-messaging-in-ukraine-and-russia\/\">announced<\/a> it\u2019s making encrypted one-to-one chats in Instagram available to adults in the two countries. And while Elon Musk said Twitter should <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/11\/16\/new-code-suggests-twitter-is-reviving-its-work-on-encrypted-dms\/\">end-to-end encrypt direct messages<\/a> prior to acquiring the company, it\u2019s <a href=\"https:\/\/www.forbes.com\/sites\/thomasbrewster\/2022\/12\/07\/elon-musk-said-twitter-needed-encrypted-messages-its-on-hold\/?sh=30af2ab49f93\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">unclear<\/a> if this will actually happen.<\/p>\n<p>Last year, <a href=\"https:\/\/themarkup.org\/pixel-hunt\/2022\/06\/15\/facebook-and-anti-abortion-clinics-are-collecting-highly-sensitive-info-on-would-be-patients\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">reporters found<\/a> that Facebook and anti-abortion clinics collect sensitive information on would-be patients. The Markup also<a href=\"https:\/\/themarkup.org\/pixel-hunt\/2022\/07\/01\/online-abortion-pill-provider-hey-jane-used-tracking-tools-that-sent-visitor-data-to-meta-google-and-others\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> reported<\/a> that Hey Jane, an online abortion pill provider, employed a series of online trackers that follow users across the internet \u2014 until the journalists reached out about the practice. More recently, ProPublica <a href=\"https:\/\/www.propublica.org\/article\/websites-selling-abortion-pills-share-sensitive-data-with-google\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">found<\/a> nine pharmacies selling abortion pills also sharing sensitive data with Google and other third-parties. All nine were recommended by <a href=\"https:\/\/www.plancpills.org\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Plan C<\/a>, which provides information about how to get abortion pills by mail. None responded to ProPublica\u2019s request for comment.<\/p>\n<p>In <a href=\"https:\/\/jessica.substack.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Abortion, Every Day<\/a>, publisher Jessica Valenti <a href=\"https:\/\/jessica.substack.com\/p\/your-complicity-will-not-protect\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">reminds<\/a> us that \u201cif you are white, have money, and the ability to travel to a state where abortion is legal \u2014 you will have a much easier time than those from marginalized communities.\u201d Everybody deserves access to reproductive health care. If the past decade is any indication, protecting essential abortion rights is going to require all of us, from doctors, nurses and attorneys to lawmakers, software engineers and voters.<\/p>\n<p><em>Sarah Mitchell-Weed contributed research.<\/em><\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>In late April, police in Nebraska received a tip saying 17-year-old Celeste Burgess had given birth to a stillborn baby and buried the body. Officers soon learned that her mother, Jessica Burgess, and a friend had helped her with transportation and burial. readabilityObject.title: How US police use digital data to prosecute abortions
readabilityObject.content:
In late April, police in Nebraska received a tip saying 17-year-old Celeste Burgess had given birth to a stillborn baby and buried the body. Officers soon learned that her mother, Jessica Burgess, and a friend had helped her with transportation and burial. The police issued citations for concealing the death of another person and false reporting. But in June, they also charged Jessica with providing an abortion for her teenage daughter. Police had made the discovery after obtaining a warrant that required Meta to hand over their conversations on Facebook Messenger. The messages, which were not encrypted, showed the two had discussed obtaining and using abortion pills.

Warrants for digital data are routine in police investigations, which makes sense, given how much time we spend online. Technology giants have for years responded to valid court orders for specific information sought by law enforcement, though some companies have done more to fight for our privacy than others. Millions of people now use apps that encrypt their calls and messages, like Signal and WhatsApp, so that no one can access their messages not even the providers themselves.

The case in Nebraska is not the first in which police have used digital data to prosecute an abortion, and it wont be the last. While digital data is rarely the main form of evidence, prosecutors use it to paint a picture in court; by showing messages sent to friends, internet searches or emails from an online pharmacy. As in the Burgess case, however, its often people around the women who first notify the authorities a doctor or nurse, a family member or a friend of a friend.

When the U.S. Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade last summer, it ended the constitutional right to abortion. In doing so, it gave states the power to regulate abortion or ban the procedure altogether, triggering a wave of abortion bans nationwide. At least 13 states now ban abortion with few or no exceptions. Georgia recently reinstated a ban after six weeks of pregnancy. And in many states, the fight over abortion access is still taking place in courtrooms.

A week after the ruling, Google announced it would delete location data for visits to abortion clinics and other medical facilities. The Electronic Frontier Foundation said we should review our privacy settings. The Digital Defense Fund encouraged us to use encrypted messaging apps. Some suggested that we delete our period tracking apps. It may seem odd to dedicate so much attention to digital privacy in the context of our reproductive rights. But a look at prosecutions between 2011 and 2022 illustrates why these conversations are needed.

In May 2011, police in Idaho charged Jennie McCormack with inducing her own abortion. The 32-year-old couldnt afford a legal procedure. Instead, she took pills purchased online. NPR reported that McCormack confided in a friend shortly after the abortion. It was this friends sister who told the police. When officers arrived at her home, they found the fetus wrapped up on her back porch.

McCormack admitted to the police that she self-induced an abortion after ingesting a pack of five pills. At trial, she told the court that the medication was FDA-approved, procured through the internet and prescribed by a physician. Years later, an appeals court noted that McCormacks sister allegedly found unspecified abortion pills online, paid $200 for them and had them shipped to McCormack in Idaho.

At the time, McCormack faced up to five years in prison. The case was eventually dismissed.

In March 2015, Indiana sentenced Purvi Patel to 20 years in prison for neglect of a dependent and feticide. Two years earlier, Patel had gone to the hospital with bleeding after delivering a child at home. She first told the medical staff that she had been 10 to 12 weeks pregnant. But when questioned by two doctors, she admitted to giving birth and said the baby was stillborn.

Patel told the doctors she had put the body in a paper bag and placed it in a dumpster behind a Target store, not far from her familys restaurant. The hospital notified the police, who searched the area and recovered the bag. A doctor who participated in the search said the baby was cold and lifeless but was an otherwise normal, healthy appearing baby.

Court documents show that police obtained a search warrant for Patels phone. An officer with training in examining electronic devices downloaded her text messages. In reviewing the data, the police found that she had discussed her abortion with at least one friend. Patel had also shared that shed obtained and taken abortion pills from Hong Kong.

An Indiana appeals court overturned the feticide conviction in July 2016. The court noted that in searching Patels iPad, police found a customer service email from InternationalDrugMart.com. The email confirmed that Patel had ordered mifepristone and misoprostol for $72. A detective ordered the same pills, presumably to confirm that it was possible to do so. Police also found Patel had visited a website titled Abortion after Twelve Weeks.

The court documents do not mention the type of phone Patel had or how police gained access to her messages. But the messages were at least three months old, suggesting that she likely did not delete the texts or the email from the online pharmacy.

Indianas attorney general decided not to appeal the courts ruling. In September 2016, Patel was resentenced to 18 months for child neglect, less time than she had already served. The judge then ordered Patels immediate release.

In April 2015, police in Arkansas arrested Anne Bynum after she gave birth to a stillborn child at home. She was charged with concealing birth and abuse of a corpse. The state also charged her friend, Karen Collins, with performing an abortion.

Bynum, who already had one child and worked a minimum-wage job, never told her parents about the pregnancy. When her pregnancy became difficult to hide, she took medications to induce labor.

In a video interview, Bynum said she delivered the baby at home by herself, in the middle of the night. She was just beautiful. Really beautiful. But eyes closed, mouth closed. Complete stillness. Bynum wrapped up the remains and went to bed. The next day, she drove to the emergency room with the remains in the front passenger seat. Bynum said she gave birth last night, but she didnt make it. Medical staff determined it had been a stillbirth.

When the hospital discharged Bynum days later, she was arrested on her way home. The sheriff put her in handcuffs and placed her in the back of the police car. Bynums trial was brief, just two days of testimony and a few minutes of jury deliberation. The judge sentenced her to six years in prison. An appeals court reversed the conviction in December 2018.

Exactly who notified the police remains unknown. The appeals court noted that Bynum told friends, her attorneys, and her priest about the pregnancy and of her intent to put the child up for adoption when it was born. On the morning after she gave birth, Bynum texted her attorney who advised her to go see a doctor. The attorney also called a funeral home and was advised to have Bynum take the fetal remains to the hospital.

Its unclear whether Bynum shared the texts herself, or if police recovered them another way.

In January 2018, Mississippi charged Latice Fisher with murder for the death of her newborn the year before. The Washington Post reported that when paramedics arrived at her home, they found a baby in the toilet, lifeless and blue, the umbilical cord still attached. The baby was pronounced dead at the hospital. Fisher initially said she didnt know she was pregnant, but later admitted that she had been aware of the pregnancy for at least a month. She also admitted to conducting internet searches for how to have a miscarriage.

Fisher reportedly voluntarily surrendered her iPhone to police. Court records show her phones memory and data were then downloaded, including but not limited to Fishers past internet activity. While reviewing that data, investigators learned that Fisher had researched buy abortion pills, mifeprisone [sic] online, misoprostol online, and buy Misoprostol Abortion Pill Online. Fisher had also apparently purchased misoprostol immediately subsequent to these searches. Another court document suggests police also searched her husbands phone.

While there is no evidence that Fisher took the pills, prosecutors used her digital data to argue that she intended to abort her pregnancy. The murder charge was eventually dismissed.

Technology companies may not have many options for handling search warrants from the police, even when the investigations relate to abortion. But companies do get to decide how much digital data they collect about people and for how long they store the information. They also get to decide whether to offer end-to-end encryption, which would give people increased privacy for all of their messages. Following Russias invasion of Ukraine last year, Meta announced its making encrypted one-to-one chats in Instagram available to adults in the two countries. And while Elon Musk said Twitter should end-to-end encrypt direct messages prior to acquiring the company, its unclear if this will actually happen.

Last year, reporters found that Facebook and anti-abortion clinics collect sensitive information on would-be patients. The Markup also reported that Hey Jane, an online abortion pill provider, employed a series of online trackers that follow users across the internet until the journalists reached out about the practice. More recently, ProPublica found nine pharmacies selling abortion pills also sharing sensitive data with Google and other third-parties. All nine were recommended by Plan C, which provides information about how to get abortion pills by mail. None responded to ProPublicas request for comment.

In Abortion, Every Day, publisher Jessica Valenti reminds us that if you are white, have money, and the ability to travel to a state where abortion is legal you will have a much easier time than those from marginalized communities. Everybody deserves access to reproductive health care. If the past decade is any indication, protecting essential abortion rights is going to require all of us, from doctors, nurses and attorneys to lawmakers, software engineers and voters.

Sarah Mitchell-Weed contributed research.
